Demographics:

Group PartyID7 responses by political leaning
```{r}
TASS2$pol_orientation2 <- NA 
TASS2$pol_orientation2[TASS2$PartyID7 == 4 | TASS2$PartyID7 == -1] = "ModerateIndependent"
TASS2$pol_orientation2[TASS2$PartyID7 == 3 | TASS2$PartyID7 == 2 | TASS2$PartyID7 == 1] = "Liberal"
TASS2$pol_orientation2[TASS2$PartyID7 > 4] = "Conservative"
```


Party Identification
```{r, echo=FALSE}

TASS2$PartyID7 <- to_factor(TASS2$PartyID7)
TASS2$PartyID7 <- recode(TASS2$PartyID7, "-1" = "Unknown", "1" = "Strong Dem", "2" = "Moderate Dem", "3" = "Lean Dem", "4" = "Independent", "5" = "Lean Rep", "6" = "Moderate Rep", "7" = "Strong Rep")

TASS2$PartyID7 <- to_factor(TASS2$PartyID7)
TASS2$PartyID7 <- recode(TASS2$PartyID7, "-1" = "Unknown", "1" = "Strong Dem", "2" = "Moderate Dem", "3" = "Lean Dem", "4" = "Independent", "5" = "Lean Rep", "6" = "Moderate Rep", "7" = "Strong Rep")
# First I'm assigning the table to a variable so that we can use this in a clean manner
PID_table <- TASS2 %>%
  group_by(PartyID7) %>% 
  summarise(n=n()) %>% 
  mutate(PartyID7perc = prop.table(n)*100) %>% 
  #So kable was a table generating function; i.e. it was meant to make html tables from data so it's not what we want unless your like making a website and you want a quick table
  #Grouping and mutating here results in the table innately. 
  mutate_if(is.numeric, round, 2)%>% #Since we don't have the round function in Kable we round if it is numeric value
  rename( Response =PartyID7, Frequency =  n , Percentage=PartyID7perc)#We have to manually rename the columns
PID_table <- as.data.frame(PID_table)#I just do not like tidy so I make it a data.frame.
PID_table

#\Fill puts different colors for different values. You had (rgb=) but from what I understand that should have been three values (red saturation, green saturation, blue saturation) where you have four. Using fill will put colors in for each bar and produce a legend when used correctly. In our case we do not want a legend because we have the xaxis. For an example of use case run the code that is commented out below:

#ggplot(PID_table, aes(x=Response, y = Percentage, fill = Response))+  geom_bar(stat = 'identity') +  ggtitle("Party Identification")

ggplot(PID_table, aes(x=Response, y = Percentage))+
  geom_bar(stat = 'identity', fill = 'turquoise4') + # We already have descriptive variable names so we do not need to redefine the axis labels in ggplot
  ggtitle("Party Identification") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust =.6)) # angle makes it such that the x axis labels are not running into each other and vjust specifies  how far from the graph we want the labels.


```


Ideology 
```{r, echo=FALSE}
TASS2$IDEO <- to_factor(TASS2$IDEO)
TASS2$IDEO <- recode(TASS2$IDEO, "-1" = "Unknown", "1" = "Extremely liberal", "2" = "Very liberal", "3" = "Somewhat liberal", "4" = "Moderate", "5" = "Somewhat conservative", "6" = "Very conservative", "7" = "Extremely conservative", "8" = "Haven't thought much about it")

ID_table <- TASS2 %>%
  group_by(IDEO) %>% 
  summarise(n=n()) %>% 
  mutate(IDEOperc = prop.table(n)*100) %>% 
  mutate_if(is.numeric, round, 2) %>% 
  rename( Response =IDEO, Frequency =  n , Percentage=IDEOperc)
ID_table <- as.data.frame(ID_table)
ID_table # You can keep the table and plot functions in the same chunk but if you want both to display both in a pdf document that results from this file you will have to actually print the table variable
ggplot(ID_table, aes(x=Response, y = Percentage)) +
   geom_bar(stat = 'identity', fill = 'turquoise4') + 
  ggtitle("Party Ideology") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, vjust =.6))
```
